bestBHT.bht: Jesus urges believers to extend care and compassion to the vulnerable, emphasizing the significance of visiting and looking after those in need. The term visited conveys the idea of offering sympathy and care, akin to our modern concept of visiting someone. This act of visiting the sick was highly esteemed, with Jewish teachings emphasizing its eternal reward and comparing the absence of such visits to shedding blood. By demonstrating care for the afflicted, believers provide comfort, support, and a tangible expression of love to their fellow human beings.

Marvin Vincent: Our word visit is from the Latin viso, to look steadfastly at, and thence to visit.
We retain the original thought in the popular phrases to see one, and to look in upon one.
Philip Schaff: Healing and release are not mentioned, these could be rendered by a few only; but visitation, sympathy, care, which all can give.
Visitation, sympathy, care, which all can give.
Healing and release are not mentioned.
Archibald T. Robertson: Clothed me (περιεβαλετε με). Second aorist middle indicative, cast something around me.
Visited me (επεσκεψασθε με). Looked after, came to see. Our 'visit' is from Latin viso, video.
John Gill: For in such a condition sometimes are the dear children of God, and members of Christ, when others, who, Dorcas like, have made coats and garments for them, and clothed them with them.
Visiting of the sick was reckoned, by the Jews, a very worthy action: they speak great things of it, and as what will be highly rewarded hereafter.

One of their Rabbins says, 'he that does not visit the sick, is as if he shed blood: says another, he that visits the sick is the cause of his living; and he that does not visit the sick, is the cause of his death: and, says a third, whoever visits the sick shall be preserved from the damnation of hell.'

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 25:36, Jesus speaks of the importance of looking after those in need, likening it to visiting Him personally. The word visited conveys the idea of looking steadfastly at, and from this, we derive our word visit. It carries the significance of showing sympathy and care for others, which anyone can offer. Though the verse does not specifically mention healing or release, it emphasizes the value of visitation, which can provide comfort and support to those facing trials. This act of visiting the sick was highly regarded by the Jews, who believed it to be a virtuous action that would be greatly rewarded in the future. Just as the Rabbis expressed, visiting the sick is seen as preserving life and avoiding damnation. Thus, Jesus underscores the importance of compassionately caring for those who are suffering by visiting them and offering support in their time of need.
